awd_abstract_narration:
The fundamental goal of this research project is to develop a route to form high performance photonic devices within the volume of a silicon wafer rather than on its surface, as is generally the case. Photonic devices are integral to many important applications in telecommunications, computing, data storage and transfer, and consumer electronics. Silicon photonics has enabled circuits that are miniaturized and integrated. These technologies will dramatically improve in speed, density, and energy efficiency if they can be successfully integrated at a high enough density as a multi-plane photonic integrated circuit (PIC). Two key projected societal impacts are (1) ultra-high speed data transfer within next generation computers using channels that route light in 3D within a chip or between chips and (2) advanced all-optical signal processing using a PIC that has numerous planes for performing operations. The project also includes the training of undergraduate and graduate researchers in photonic device/circuit theory, microfabrication, metrology, and numerical simulation. Research and teaching will be closely integrated through three of the PI's courses: Materials in Nanotechnology, Integrated Optoelectronics, and Principles of Experimental Research. Participation of students from underrepresented groups will be broadened through undergrad research and by leveraging large existing K-12 outreach initiatives that will impact greater than a thousand students.
The PIs propose a proof-of-concept project to realize multiple planes of interconnected micro-optic elements, waveguides, and passive photonic devices within the volume of a silicon wafer. Subsurface gradient refractive index (GRIN) devices will be fabricated within porous silicon (PSi) or silica (PSiO2 = oxidized PSi) via two-photon lithography to selectively polymerize photoresist within the porous host. This direct laser writing (DLW) approach enables index control (nPSi = 1.4-1.9, nPSiO2 = 1.15-1.3) at each voxel. Complex GRIN elements (e.g., compound apochromatic lenses, photonic nanojet emitters, diffractive and photonic bandgap structures, spiral phase plates, and index/mode matching bamboo-shaped tapers) plus conventional silicon photonic elements (e.g., interferometers, gratings, and microring multiplexers and filters) can all be fabricated in a self-aligned manner with < 1 micron critical dimensions across a 4" wafer. The research seeks to advance knowledge in the fields of subsurface fabrication and photonic integration. The interdisciplinary team of 2 PIs, 2 grad students, and 2 undergrad students will leverage their experience and training in GRIN PSi and PSiO2 optics, DLW, optical device/circuit theory and design, computational electromagnetics, imaging, metrology, and nanomanufacturing to answer fundamental scientific questions about the fabrication of complex optics by addressing five major goals:
1.	Investigate and apply polymerization-based index control and optical characteristics in mesoporous scaffold-enabled two-photon lithography.
2.	Measure the spectral dependence of the refractive index and absorption coefficient (400 - 1700 nm) as well as the 3D point spread function of the writing process.
3.	Develop software tools to: (a) optimize the 3D index profile to achieve a given optical functionality and (b) determine the necessary two-photon lithography exposure conditions to realize said profile.
4.	Design, fabricate, characterize, and model novel GRIN elements and subsurface 3D waveguides.
5.	Demonstrate the aforementioned monolithically integrated 8-plane PIC and optical interposer.
Demonstration of previously unachievable photonic geometries and functionalities will not only create a new paradigm for future PIC architectures but will also lead to new scientific applications such as lab-in-chip, interferometry, metrology, imaging, and quantum optics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project has focused on advancing a new direct writing technique for fabricating micro-optics: subsurface controllable refractive index via beam exposure (SCRIBE). Rather than patterning optical elements on the surface of a wafer with illumination shone through a photomask, as is standard in traditional silicon-on-insulator (SOI) photonics, SCRIBE rasters a focused laser beam to form polymer structures within a porous medium. Over the course of the research project, silicon etching and oxidation processes have been developed that enable 60 micron thick porous silicon dioxide thin films with approximately 80% porosity (that is, mostly pores filled with air). The thin film's physical properties were experimentally validated using ellipsometry and data fitting. This film thickness allowed for the possibility of fabricating dense, multi-layered photonic integrated circuits (PICs) within its volume. This project also contributed to the direct training in research of 12 graduate students, 12 undergraduates, and 1 postdoc.

Several important building blocks of PICs have been demonstrated, including coupling lenses, microring resonators, Mach-Zehnder interferometers (MZIs), and multimode interferometers (MMIs). With the use of coupling lenses, the loss of a fiber to waveguide to fiber optical interconnect was reduced from 50 dB to 2.3 dB across the entire 1250 − 1650 nm wavelength range, which is an important range for modern telecommunications. By measuring microrings and observing a quality factor on the order of 60,000, we could estimate an upper bound on our propagation loss of 3 dB/cm. These values are competitive with conventional surface-based planar waveguide technologies but have the advantage of 3-dimensional volumetric scalability. The waveguide shape was characterized versus depth to enable lithographic corrections to further reduce loss. When moving large distances on the mechanical stage, small errors in steering the writing laser can occur, which can introduce significant loss of light propagating in a waveguide. By measuring these systematic rotational and dilation errors ahead of time, we compensated for them and reduced loss in very long waveguides across a PIC.

The capability to route 3D waveguides under or above one another with no additional fabrication difficulty and with very little (optical) crosstalk is highly desirable for creating more complex PICs in the future. Previously, the complexity of PICs has been limited by planar designs, such as with SOI. More complex integrated PICs could have applications in on-chip optical communications or all-optical computing, both of which are emerging fields of research.

Another key advantage of SCRIBE is its ability to make gradient refractive index (GRIN) structures by modulating the writing laser power. In other words, we can control how light refracts locally by modulating refractive index on the sub-micron scale within our micro-optical devices. When the writing laser is operated near the threshold region, the photoresist may be partially polymerized, resulting in an intermediate refractive index between that of its unpolymerized and fully polymerized state. This method is unique in that it theoretically yields continuous index control from the background index of the porous silica up to nearly the index of the solid polymer. However, in practice, the intensity of the laser varies slightly across the write field.

This variation in laser power (and correspondingly variation in refractive index) was the motivation for the development of a calibration procedure. By precisely measuring these inaccuracies and using different motorized stages synergistically, this research project achieved a device-to-device refractive index standard deviation of less than 0.005. Furthermore, general-purpose code has been developed for correcting these errors when fabricating any design of the user's choice. Once the calibration data has been collected for a given instrument, no further iteration or trial-and-error edit of a design is necessary. A given design can be input to the program, and the design will be accurately fabricated. This calibration procedure has real impacts on fabricated device performance, such as the intensity in the focus of a micro-lens, or the wavelength at which a microring resonates. By fabricating several example devices with and without corrections, it was definitively shown that significant improvements exist in each case.

Various novel GRIN elements have been fabricated, including multiple designs of photonic nanojet generators that had previously only been theorized. These designs have potential in fields such as high-resolution optical metrology and lithography. By having nearly complete control over the refractive index within the porous medium, the output light from a given design can be precisely shaped as needed by the application. The level of flexibility enabled by SCRIBE after this research project was completed is unprecedented.
